There is no gaiety, no freedom, no warmth in the great room.

of man surround her as with the walls of a dungeon. The wall
may conceal a Lady Ann who is merry and gay; it must
conceal laughter, love, good humour, and all the trifles
of daily life. But behind that stiff garment of Eizabethan
prose who can tell what emotions are alive? They are

pomous
                  pompous
                ; they are

                  solemn
                ; they are longwinded;

We

we know

                  nothing
                 about the public who had the books read aloud
to them.
